title: Stocks in focus today: Bharti Airtel, Nestle India and more
text:
Other Articles Amtek Auto, Castex Technologies shares plunge on Sebi probe S&P downgrades Brazil, Indian companies may take a hit Vedanta shares fall over 4% as S&P uncertain over merger of Cairn India The BSE Sensex and NSE Nifty opened in negative terrain on Thursday following weak global cues. At 9.24 am, Sensex was down 351.98 points at 25,367.60. Similarly, Nifty was down 116.60 points at 7,702.00 during the same time.
Below are the stocks that are likely to be in focus today
Bharti Airtel : Telecom major Bharti Airtel and Malaysia-based Axiata Group have begun talks to merge their operations in Bangladesh to create the second-largest operator in that country.
Telecom companies: The stocks of telcos companies will be in focus as the union cabinet on Wednesday approved guidelines on spectrum trading.
Grasim Industries: The company on Wednesday had said that the Competition Commission of India (CCI) has approved the amalgamation of Aditya Birla Chemicals (India) with Grasim Industries.
Steel: Stocks of the steel companies will be in focus after Director General of Safeguards (DGS) recommended imposition of a provisional safeguard duty of 20 per cent on certain category of imports with a view to protect domestic producers from surge in imports.
Tata Steel: Tata Steel on Wednesday said production of coke has started at its Kalinganagar project in Odisha and it is set for commissioning of the first phase of its 3 million tonne steel plant.
Shree Pushkar Chemicals & Fertilisers: The company’s stocks will make its debut on the bourses.
Nestle India: Suresh Narayanan, MD of Nestle India said on Wednesday that the company is planning to re-launch it popular instant noodles brand Maggi in the country by the end of the year if it gets a go ahead from the Bombay High Court.
Dr Reddy’s: Dr Reddy’s Laboratories and US-based medical nutrition company PanTheryx on Wednesday announced a multi-country supply and licensing agreement.
Jewellery stocks: Stocks of jewellery companies will be in focus after the government approved gold bond and gold monetisation schemes to reduce the metal’s demand in physical form.
